q: It was meant to point out there was broad support in Eastern Europe and that France and Germany did not speak for the entire continent. ''Ironically, my comment was unintentional,'' Donald Rumsfeld writes. I had meant to say France and Germany represented ''old NATO' not` old Europe'. ''In any event, the phrase` old Europe' entered the vernacular. The segments of Americans that preferred calling french fries` freedom fries' loved it,'' he writes. '''The elites in Paris

were full occupied,'' writes Donald Rumsfeld . Yet Bush called for ''creative'' options to militarily engage Iraq. Donald Rumsfeld twice tried to quit in the wake of the Abu Ghraib scandal, which he says left me feeling punched in the gut. Saying he felt his resignation would demonstrate accountability and help the administration move beyond the scandal, he gave letters to Bush, who refused and instead suggested firing Colin Powell Richard Myers, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of

for an executive who is transitioning out of the CEO role_ and may even be unusual for sitting CEOs, said David Wise, senior principal at management consulting firm Hay Group. But given Eric Schmidt 's success, the board clearly wants to retain his guidance for the next four years. ''It's a signal to shareholders that he'll continue to steer the boat,'' Wise added. Eric Schmidt , 55, is being replaced as Google Inc. 's CEO by co-founder Larry Page.

. The news of the change rocked Silicon Valley, with analysts and company insiders offering varying theories. Some said Mr. Eric Schmidt was tired of the day-to-day hassles of management. Mr. Eric Schmidt said in the interview, I would tell you, frankly, a decade is a long time to be a C.E.O., and Larry will discover this. Others say Mr. Page always planned to re-assert his authority at some point. ''Larry has wanted to be C.E.O., so that's not a surprise,'' said a former Google sales executive
